payload.text:
üöÄ Automate

AI Automation & AI Agents That Scale Your Business ‚Äî Without Hiring

We build intelligent systems that replace manual work, streamline operations, and drive revenue using AI agents and automation.

üëâ Book a Free Automation Strategy Call

üîπ Hero Section

Automate Your Business. Multiply Your Output. Reduce Your Costs.

Stop wasting hours on repetitive tasks.
Automate helps businesses implement AI agents and smart workflows that handle sales, support, operations, and data ‚Äî 24/7.

‚úî AI Agents for Sales, Support & Ops
‚úî Workflow Automation (n8n, Zapier, Make)
‚úî API Integrations & System Automation
‚úî Custom AI Tools & Dashboards

üëâ Get Your Free Automation Audit

üîπ Who We Help

We work with:

Agencies & Consultants

SaaS Companies

E-commerce Brands

Real Estate Teams

Coaches & Course Creators

Growing SMBs

If your business uses:
CRM, forms, email, spreadsheets, Slack, Notion, Airtable, Shopify, or custom tools ‚Äî we can automate it.

üîπ What We Do
ü§ñ AI Agent Development

We build intelligent AI agents that:

Qualify leads automatically

Respond to customers instantly

Handle bookings, support, and follow-ups

Make decisions using your data

Learn and improve over time

Includes:

Chat agents

Voice agents

Sales agents

Support agents

Internal ops agents

Multi-agent systems

‚öô Workflow Automation

We design end-to-end workflows using:
n8n, Zapier, Make.com, Power Automate, and custom APIs.

Automations include:

Lead capture & routing

CRM updates

Email & SMS follow-ups

Social media automation

Reporting & dashboards

Data sync across tools

Error handling & monitoring

üîå API & System Integrations

We connect your tools ‚Äî even if they don‚Äôt natively integrate.

REST APIs

Webhooks

Custom connectors

Legacy system integration

Internal tool automation

üìä Business Operations Automation

We automate:

Onboarding & offboarding

Invoicing & payments

Task management

Team workflows

KPI reporting

Data pipelines

Compliance workflows

üß† AI-Powered Tools & Dashboards

We build:

Internal business tools

AI-powered calculators & audits

Custom dashboards

Lead magnets

Intelligent reporting systems

üîπ How It Works

1Ô∏è‚É£ Audit
We analyze your current tools, workflows, and bottlenecks.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Design
We architect the optimal automation + AI system.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Build
We implement workflows, AI agents, and integrations.

4Ô∏è‚É£ Test
We test, optimize, and ensure reliability.

5Ô∏è‚É£ Deploy & Support
We deploy and support your system long-term.

üîπ Why Automate?

‚úî Expert in AI agents & automation platforms
‚úî Fast turnaround
‚úî Secure & compliant workflows
‚úî No-code + code solutions
‚úî Custom-built for your business
‚úî ROI-focused ‚Äî not just ‚Äúautomation‚Äù

Our systems reduce manual work by up to 60%, improve response time by 80%, and help businesses scale without hiring.

üîπ Tech Stack

Automation:
n8n, Zapier, Make.com, Power Automate, Workato

AI & Agents:
OpenAI (GPT), Claude, LLaMA, HuggingFace, LangChain, LangGraph, CrewAI, AutoGPT, Retell AI, Vapi AI

Backend & Apps:
Python, JavaScript, FastAPI, Node.js, React, Next.js, Webhooks, REST APIs

Business Tools:
HubSpot, Salesforce, Airtable, Notion, Slack, Google Sheets, Shopify, Typeform, JotForm, Gmail, WhatsApp, and more.

üîπ Use Cases

AI-powered lead qualification

AI sales assistant & booking agent

AI customer support automation

CRM & pipeline automation

Marketing automation

Onboarding automation

Internal ops automation

Reporting & dashboards

Data scraping & enrichment

Custom business tools

üîπ Pricing (Starting Points)

Starter Automation
Simple workflow or AI agent setup
‚úî 1‚Äì2 workflows
‚úî 1 platform integration
‚úî Delivery in 2‚Äì3 days

Growth Automation
Multi-step workflows + AI agents
‚úî 5‚Äì10 workflows
‚úî Multiple tool integrations
‚úî AI logic + CRM
‚úî Delivery in 5‚Äì7 days

Scale Automation
End-to-end business automation system
‚úî 10+ workflows
‚úî AI agents + dashboards
‚úî APIs + custom logic
‚úî Delivery in 10‚Äì14 days

üëâ Request a Custom Quote

üîπ Call to Action

Ready to automate your business?

üëâ Book a Free Automation Strategy Call
üëâ Get a Free Automation Audit
üëâ Message Us to Get Started Today

üîπ Footer

Automate
AI Automation ‚Ä¢ AI Agents ‚Ä¢ Business Systems ‚Ä¢ API Integrations
Serving clients worldwide.

Goal: Generate Automate website

**Defining the Application's Purpose**

I'm solidifying the vision. The goal is clear: a full-fledged React application, expertly crafted with TypeScript and Tailwind CSS, destined for "Automate." The provided content serves as a starting point. I'm focusing on the Hero section content, so I can ensure it aligns with the agency's needs.


**Analyzing Section Structure**

I'm now deep-diving into the site's structure, specifically the required sections: "Who We Help," "What We Do," "How It Works," "Why Automate," "Tech Stack," "Use Cases," "Pricing," and Call to Action. I'm visualizing the layout in terms of content and user flow, ensuring a logical progression that's intuitive for the target audience.


**Outlining Functionality Further**

I'm now concretizing the sections: a "How It Works" timeline, stats and benefits in "Why Automate," and a categorized "Tech Stack" list. I've designed the Pricing section with tiered cards (Starter, Growth, Scale), a prominent CTA, and a standard Footer.

\n\n

**Specifying Core Technologies**

I'm solidifying the tech choices. I'm selecting React 18+ with TypeScript, Tailwind CSS, Lucide React icons, and Framer Motion for animations to make the site feel impressive. I'll use either Inter or Roboto fonts.


**Planning Component Development**

I'm now focusing on specific components: ContactCTA and Footer are priorities. I'll also be creating reusable UI elements.

I'm developing a design draft, considering the color palette (dark background, light text, accents), hero section with large typography, and glowing effects. Services will include hover effects and the "Process" section will feature a vertical timeline. I've broken the implementation into steps: metadata setup, initial HTML, React app mount, and component creation, avoiding custom CSS files. I'm taking into account the use of Lucide React icons, and Framer for animations.


**Implementing Animation and Design**

I'm now integrating Framer Motion to elevate the user experience, focusing on fade-in and stagger effects for a dynamic "world-class" feel. The design will be mobile-first and the content will be laid out with a responsive approach. The metadata, HTML, and index file are written, and sections are being imported into the App. I'm focusing on a strong gradient headline in the Hero section, and simple grid layouts for Services and TechStack.

entries.description: Main HTML entry point with Tailwind CSS and Fonts

payload.text: Just simply add this link to every butons used in the site: https://wa.me/923149525452
Just simply add this link to every butons used in the site: https://wa.me/923149525452

**Identifying Button Targets**

I'm currently focused on pinpointing all the button-like elements across the site. My primary goal is to identify any instances that trigger a call to action. I plan to wrap each relevant element in an anchor tag that points to the desired WhatsApp link.


**Modifying Button Behaviors**

I'm now diving into the code, specifically the listed files. I'm swapping out the identified button elements with anchor tags, or wrapping existing buttons with them, to ensure the WhatsApp link is correctly implemented. I will also incorporate `target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer"` for external links, and keep it semantically correct with simple `href` attributes on `a` tags styled as buttons.


**Updating Button Integrations**

I've just finished the code changes across `Navbar.tsx`, `Hero.tsx`, `Pricing.tsx`, and `CallToAction.tsx`. I updated all specified buttons to anchor tags, replacing the button components with `<a href="https://wa.me/923149525452">` where needed. Furthermore, I verified there are no buttons in `WhoWeHelp`, `Services`, `Process`, `WhyAutomate`, `TechStack`, and `Footer`, therefore the implementation is now complete.


**Analyzing Button Components**

I'm now thoroughly reviewing the codebase, paying close attention to the use of "button" semantics, specifically Call to Action (CTA) buttons. Standard navigation links are left alone, as they serve internal purposes and are not CTAs, although I will check the footer as well. I'm focusing on the component files. I can already see that `Navbar.tsx` contains the CTA.


**Implementing WhatsApp Links**

I've incorporated the WhatsApp links into the `Navbar.tsx` and `Hero.tsx` components. I wrapped the "Book Strategy Call" element in an anchor tag and modified the Hero button to link to the WhatsApp URL. Both are now live and integrated. I can now move on to testing, to see that they work as expected.


**Adding Pricing Page Links**

I'm now integrating WhatsApp links into the pricing section of `Pricing.tsx`. I've added anchor tags with the WhatsApp URL to the pricing tier elements, ensuring each CTA leads to a chat. I'll make sure the styling remains consistent with the rest of the site's button design.


**Integrating Call-to-Actions**

I'm currently updating the `components/CallToAction.tsx` file. I'm swapping the existing button with an anchor tag that links to the WhatsApp number, incorporating the correct CSS classes. The main CTA element is now updated, and the custom quote request also now features the same link. I'll ensure consistency across styles.



**Verifying Button Semantics**

I'm now focusing on `Footer.tsx`. The links there are for navigation, not call-to-action buttons, so I won't modify them. I'm noting that when replacing `<button>` with `<a>`, classes like `w-full` may not function without also applying `block`, `inline-block`, or `flex` for proper styling. I'll need to check the effect of `w-full` on anchor tags.

payload.text: Search for the errors, and resolve it, (because it shows blank page on Vercel)

**Investigating Blank Page**

I'm now diving into the provided files to pinpoint the cause of the blank page on Vercel. I've started with `index.html` to look for issues in the base structure. I'm focusing on the importmap and potential external dependencies being incorrectly loaded, and cross-referencing this against other files to identify the root cause.


**Verifying Import Paths**

I've confirmed the import map in `index.html` correctly maps `react-dom/client` to the esm.sh URL. My analysis reveals that `react-dom/client` should resolve accurately. However, I'm considering potential Vercel-specific issues like incorrect entry points or runtime errors that might still lead to the blank page. I'll need to further investigate these potential causes.


**Identifying Missing Script**

I've realized a critical issue. My focus shifted to import paths and Vercel, but I completely missed the absence of the crucial script tag loading the application in `index.html`. It's the reason for the blank page! No script, no app. I now understand this static site structure. I am checking the index.html content to ensure the index.tsx is imported and run.


**Confirming Script Absence**

I've re-examined `index.html`, and can confirm my initial observation. The file is missing the critical script tag that would load and execute `index.tsx`. The importmap is present, but without this link, the application will not run. This is the root cause: no script, no display.


**Analyzing File Extensions**

I'm now investigating the impact of file extensions with raw ES modules in the browser. My findings show local files require extensions like `.tsx` or `.js` in import statements, but this project seems not to have a compile step. So, imports like `import App from './App'` in `index.tsx` would fail in a browser unless transpiled or bundled. I need to figure out why this doesn't seem to be a problem, given the project structure, or if this is the root cause.


**Clarifying Bundler Assumption**

I'm now understanding how the bundler like Vite might be at play here. Thinking about it, the file extensions issue is probably handled by a build process. The project's intention seems to be a standard React setup, given the prompt. I think there's a build command. But, I still need to ensure the entry script is included in `index.html`. It should look like this: `<script type="module" src="./index.tsx"></script>`.


**Verifying Root Creation**

I can confirm my previous suspicion: the `react-dom/client` import in `index.tsx` is likely correct, since the project is using `createRoot`. The import map and esm.sh seem to be working well together for `react-dom/client`, based on the available information. Now, the blank page is because of a missing script tag.


**Clarifying React Version**

I'm now zeroing in on the React version. Thinking about it, the issue might be related to React 18 or pre-release React 19 compatibility. My focus shifted to import maps and ensuring the versions of React and React DOM are properly aligned for the `createRoot` method. I will revisit the import map's versions.


**Validating Version Compatibility**

I'm now zeroing in on the React and React-DOM versions defined in the import map. The versions being used are `19.2.4`, which I'm skeptical of, considering React 19 is not stable. I'm verifying the esm.sh URLs and the potential for a 404 or unexpected behavior due to the version. I need to ensure version compatibility. I'm also planning to check how the project uses the versions. Furthermore, I will address the missing script tag.

I will also update `index.tsx` to use named import for `createRoot` just to be safe.
`import { createRoot } from 'react-dom/client';`
Finally, I will verify the file paths to ensure the project works.


**Revisiting Script Tag**

I've circled back to the crucial missing script tag in `index.html`. My previous XML output confirms I omitted it! No wonder the page is blank. This is a clear oversight. I should have included `<script type="module" src="./index.tsx"></script>` within the `body` to load the application. Now I need to ensure it's present in the updated HTML output.


**Confirming Import Map Inclusion**

I've observed a critical detail: the `importmap` is present in the provided `index.html`. This wasn't present previously! It is now present but still lacks the essential `<script>` tag. My focus is now ensuring the `importmap` is correctly loaded. I'm updating `index.tsx` with named imports to match latest React best practices. I'll make sure `createRoot` is imported as a named import. I also need to verify the paths are working.


**Refining HTML and Imports**

I'm now implementing the plan: I've updated `index.html` to include the crucial script tag and revised the import map, changing React and React-DOM versions to `18`. I also updated `index.tsx` to use named imports for `createRoot`. The components, `App.tsx` particularly, seem okay and standard, assuming the environment handles imports without file extensions. I will ensure the updated HTML output includes everything.


**Confirming CSS Frameworks**

I'm now checking the integration of Tailwind CSS and Google Fonts. I'm making sure these external resources are correctly linked within `<head>` of `index.html`. My focus has shifted from the JavaScript side to ensuring the styles are correctly applied. I also need to ensure these don't interfere with React's rendering, potentially causing unexpected behavior.



**Analyzing CSS Effects**

I'm now assessing the applied CSS for Tailwind and Glassmorphism effects in the project. Specifically, the `<style>` tag includes `background-color` and `backdrop-filter` rules. These styles might require careful handling in conjunction with React, but they are unlikely to cause a blank page. The styling itself seems straightforward, so I'll verify their structure and interaction.



**Verifying Package Versions**

I'm now zeroing in on package versions, especially `lucide-react`, given the recent code. The original input has `^0.563.0`, but I'm thinking about sticking with `0.344.0` for greater stability with ESM, as this is proven. However, since the user's version is valid and most likely recent, I'll keep the `^0.563.0`. I need to review and ensure all imports in `index.tsx` are correct.


**Addressing Import Dependencies**

I'm now focusing on import paths and potential bundler assumptions. I've realized the absence of file extensions in the `App` import within `index.tsx` is likely handled by a bundler. Assuming a bundler environment like Vite, I'm verifying the import and exploring how the lack of file extensions might still work seamlessly. I'm also now addressing the potentially problematic React version `19.2.4`, replacing it with `18`. I've updated both the import and code to reflect this. I've verified the `lucide-react` import.


**Finalizing Script Inclusion**

I'm now implementing the final plan. I've updated `index.html` to include the script tag and fixed the import map, changing the React and React-DOM versions to 18. I've also updated `index.tsx` to use named imports for `createRoot`. The `lucide-react` version is as suggested. I am confident now.



**Validating Font Links**

I'm now verifying the Google Fonts links in `<head>`. I'm making sure `fonts.gstatic.com` and `fonts.googleapis.com` are properly linked for font rendering. Ensuring no errors will prevent font styling and visual consistency.


**Confirming CSS Structure**

I'm now cross-referencing the included CSS in the `<style>` tag, with the HTML structure, to make sure the provided styles align with the elements. I'm focusing on the `glass-card` class, ensuring it's applied correctly. The styles seem straightforward; I'm checking for conflicts or unexpected side effects within React. I'm also confirming the styles are present.

The blank page issue on Vercel is likely caused by two main problems in the provided files:

1.  **Missing Script Tag**: The `index.html` file is missing the `<script type="module" src="./index.tsx"></script>` tag, so the React application never loads.
2.  **Invalid Package Versions**: The `importmap` specifies React version `^19.2.4`, which does not exist (React 19 is currently in RC/Beta and typically doesn't have a 19.2 version yet). This likely causes 404 errors when trying to fetch the libraries.

I will fix the `index.html` to include the script tag and use stable React 18 versions, and update `index.tsx` to use the correct named import for `createRoot`.

entries.description: Add missing entry script and fix importmap versions
Use named import for createRoot to ensure compatibility

payload.text:
**Analyzing the Replacement**

I'm currently focused on identifying all instances of "Automate" within the application's files. My immediate task is to accurately pinpoint occurrences needing replacement with "Autobizz", while carefully preserving context where "automate" functions as a verb, like in "Ready to automate your business". I'm meticulously scanning the codebase to ensure no unintended modifications occur.


**Evaluating Text Replacements**

I've moved on to examining the content of the identified files, specifically focusing on the visible text that needs alteration. I'm prioritizing direct text replacements first to accurately reflect the user's initial guidance. I'm now cross-referencing file names with content to ensure holistic changes. It seems I will also need to rename some components to match the content in addition to simply replacing text strings.


**Assessing Branding Changes**

I'm now carefully examining the implications of a broader brand identity shift. Analyzing `components/Navbar.tsx`, I note the direct replacement of "Automate" with "Autobizz". However, reviewing `components/Hero.tsx`, I'm reconsidering the user's intent concerning the slogan, as "Autobizz Your Business" sounds awkward. Considering the `index.html` title and the footer components, I'm noting several instances of "Automate" that may need alteration for consistency. I must take extra care with the "Why Automate?" title in `components/WhyAutomate.tsx`.


**Refining Slogan Strategy**

I'm now carefully navigating how to best address the core slogan. My current approach prioritizes renaming "Why Automate?" to "Why Autobizz?" while keeping the file and component name. I've noted that the "Autobizz Your Business" slogan is not ideal and am working to brainstorm some alternatives. I'm focusing on the `metadata.json` name, the `index.html` title tag, the `Navbar` and `Footer` logo text, and the copyright text.


**Verifying Name Adjustments**

I'm now diving into the specific branding instances, confirming the replacement strategy. I'm focusing on the instances of the brand name "Automate" within the file list, and ensuring that "Automate" is consistently updated to "Autobizz" where it is used as a proper noun. I am specifically reviewing the `metadata.json` name, `index.html` title, `Navbar` and `Footer` logo text, and copyright, as well as the header in the `WhyAutomate` component. I've re-examined the intent behind leaving "automate" as a verb where appropriate.


**Confirming Content Adjustments**

I'm now cross-referencing file content and branding. Analyzing `components/Pricing.tsx`, I'll preserve "Automation" in plan names, and "automate" as a verb. Similarly, in `components/CallToAction.tsx`, I am maintaining the verb "automate". However, my focus is now on systematically updating branding instances across: `metadata.json`, `index.html`, `Navbar.tsx`, `Footer.tsx` (x2), and the heading in `WhyAutomate.tsx`. Finally, I'm reconsidering the title in `Hero.tsx`, as I'm thinking, "Autobizz Your Business", or perhaps "Scale Your Business with Autobizz."


**Prioritizing Strategic Replacement**

I'm now zeroing in on the slogan and component titles, considering various replacement options. Given the instruction to replace "automate" with "autobizz", I'm leaning towards the direct replacement, "Autobizz Your Business", for the initial `components/Hero.tsx` title, while simultaneously considering alternatives. I am looking to modify the file title in `components/WhyAutomate.tsx` from "Why Automate?" to "Why Autobizz?". In `metadata.json` and `index.html`, I will update the title.


**Implementing Direct Changes**

I'm now implementing the determined replacements. I've updated the logo and text in `Navbar.tsx` and `Footer.tsx`. The title in `WhyAutomate.tsx` is changed to "Why Autobizz?". In `Hero.tsx`, I've changed the H1 tag to "Autobizz Your Business". I'm maintaining the verb "automate" as appropriate in other files.

To change the brand name from **Automate** to **Autobizz**, I will update the application metadata, the visible logo text in the navigation and footer, and the "Why Automate?" section header.

I will keep the word "automate" where it is used as a verb (e.g., "Automate Your Business", "Ready to automate..."), as "Autobizz" is a brand name and doesn't fit grammatically in those contexts.

Here are the changes:

**Initiating the Search**

**Locating Key Phrases**
